poem:
### Nine Bodies

In Los Tríos, whispering,  
dust settles on soldiers' boots—  
nine whispers they await,  
chill of steel caressing stories,  
echoes of silent tongues  
curled in morgue's repose.  
Red letters dance above,  
a tapestry of intrigue.  
What are lives,  
but words unwritten,  
waiting to unfold  
beneath a pulpy sky?
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Nine Bodies in a Mexican Morgue review – nothing has given me greater joy this year We open, bright red Pulp Fiction-y letters tell us, on “Day Nine”. Not “Day One”! Intrigued? You betcha! We are in Los Tríos, Mexico – watching a woman watch the Mexican military police await delivery of nine bodies, to store in an isolated facility’s morgue. Which is fortuitous, because this is the beginning of a new thriller by Anthony". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
